Message.Title: eBay reports 14.1% revenue increase in second quarter financial results
Message.Msg: Search for "SEC Live Filings Digest" to find out more. Online auction giant eBay (EBAY) announced its financial results for second quarter fiscal 2013, reporting a revenue increase of 14.1% to $3.9B from $3.4B a year ago. Despite the strong revenue growth, the company did not live up to investor expectations with respect to net income, reporting $640M, a 7.5% decrease from last year’s $692M. Comparing earnings per share, eBay investors earned $0.49 per share, $0.04 less per share from last year. eBay’s payment unit PayPal saw revenue increase 20% from $1.36B last year to $1.62B this quarter. PayPal has been credited for a large part of eBay’s overall success as PayPal strives to be the payment method of choice for not only online transactions, but brick-and-mortar stores as well. eBay CEO John Donahoe remarked that the company is strong and he remains confident in its ability to meet and exceed internal goals.

Message.Title: CCUR to Soon Be #1 On NASDAQ's Top Percentage Gainers List!
Message.Msg: A major wave of M&A activity is beginning in the cable TV industry. Programming costs are soaring through the roof and cable TV operators need to consolidate and gain leverage to push costs down. As cable TV operators merge and achieve big cost savings, they will rapidly increase their spending on technologies that will fuel the industry's future growth. Cable TV operator stocks are rallying, but the biggest gainers during this summer's consolidation wave will be the industry's leading technology vendors. We could soon see the largest tech vendors like Cisco (CSCO) rapidly acquire smaller cable TV tech pure plays like Seachange (SEAC) and Concurrent (CCUR). An analyst at Brean Capital issued a research note about SEAC in December, which speculated that it's a takeover target, "Because of SEAC's leading position in key areas of MSO investment, it is not likely to remain an independent company in an industry consolidation scenario." The consolidation scenario they alluded to is now getting underway, much sooner than expected. SEAC reached new 52-week highs the past three trading days! Yesterday, SEAC hit a new 52-week high of $12.72 and closed at $12.58. It has a market cap of $412mm with $114.23mm in cash and an enterprise value of $297.77mm or 1.91X revenues of $156.11mm. SEAC is rising due to takeover speculation and CCUR will likely be next to explode! Search for and read the article 'Motorola, Cisco Buyouts Vex VOD Market' to see how CCUR is also a takeover target with Arris reported to have shown interest. CCUR just surpassed SEAC to become the #1 VOD tech vendor, while Arris is #4 and could easily acquire CCUR to dominate the market - both companies are based in Atlanta! CCUR needs to rise to $16.35 just to match SEAC's enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.91! When CCUR files their 10-K next month, their trailing non-GAAP EPS will likely reach $0.50 and surpass SEAC's non-GAAP EPS of $0.44!

Topic.Title: Cramer Lovers

Message.Msg: On manipulating AAPL: "Apple, it’s very important to spread the rumor that both Verizon and AT&T decided they didn’t like the phone… and this is very easy because the people who write about Apple want that story and you can claim that it’s credible because you spoke to someone at Apple because Apple doesn’t issue any statements." Cramer says he would do this in conjunction with placing large put orders (1,000 blocks) to create the impression that something was happening and then HE would call Pisani and say, "hey, something is happening, there’s a lot of put buying going on at Apple... What’s important when you’re in that hedge fund mode, is not to do anything remotely truthful, because the truth is so against your view that it’s important to create a new truth, to develop a fiction. And the fiction is developed by almost anybody who is down like 2% to up 6% a year…"

Topic.Title: FYI

Message.Msg: I am an ebay seller for over 12 years - i used to sell a lot and made over $800 in fees for ebay every month - while making about $10000 per month for myself. Now i can barely sell $1000 a month and ebay/paypal take 12% of my totals sales and shipping costs. Makes it not worth my while anymore - ebay doesnot have the sudience it once did - so now I am slowly selling out inventory to close up shop - many of the better sellers are moving elsewhere - a fact

Message.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive
Message.Msg: EBAY is dropping by nearly 7%, on weak forward guidance by the CEO. The retrenchment is confirmed by very high volume of 37 million shares. This correction was foreshadowed by aggressive insiders selling of 2.1 million shares. Sellers included the Chairman, CEO and CFO. Furthermore large institutions have recently sold 14.7 million shares. The stock’s technical’s are also weakening. The MACD is trending lower. EBAY is now trading below the 20 and 50 day SMA, and is approaching the 200 day SMA. The 5 day EMA is nearing a negative crossover of the 13 day EMA. Absent a positive new catalyst to reverse the correction, the stock could correct to the $ 50.09- $ 50.25 near term support level. The medium and longer term prospects for EBAY are positive, but in the near term the trend is negative. The short term risk adjusted return is biased to the downside into next week.

Topic.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive

Message.Msg: should be a good buying op coming in the next few days.

Topic.Title: FYI

Message.Msg: While I agree with you, correction John, you also pay Paypal fees, so it's 13%. Add in listign fees and store fees and for some of us, it can be as high as 20%. You're also forgetting to mention, it's 13% straight across the board now. Sellers of higher priced items no longer have an FVF cap, but in all honesty, Amazon has always been straight across the board with no cap.

Message.Title: praying
Message.Msg: dear god, let's ebay drop to $48 my god is better than your god

Topic.Title: FYI

Message.Msg: I hear your complaints and somewhat agree with you but as someone who has been in business for years before eBay, it was no different processing credit cards through a merchant's account. Get too many complaints and the bank will put you into high risk category. don't clean up your act and you're toast. While I agree, eBay's methods and policies seem tough at times, for me, I follow them and have absolutely no significant problems. Of course, I have to kick a few thieves refunds every month but the loss percentage is far less than shoplifters were at my brick&mortar store. Point is, accurately photo and describe your items, treat customers with respect, even if they are trying to scam you, and realize, loss is a part of business. No reason to get upset, worried or engraged. Move on.

Topic.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive

Message.Msg: I concur that EBAY has begun a price new discovery process that may well challenger the $ 50 low on June 24. This time however the correction is due to a rough patch ahead envisioned by the CEO, as compared to an overall market pullback. At the end of the price discovery EBAY, EBAY's Mid to L/T prospects are favorable. S/T it may be a falling knife. Until this is resolved, caution is advisable.

Topic.Title: Cramer Lovers

Message.Msg: I was going to mention Tokyo Joe but in reality he was a small fish who got fried for being a #$%$. He'd buy ahead of his recommendations. What a geek. The guy I always admired was my buddy Steve's uncle "Crazy Frank" - guy had his own call sign trading out of his NY condo. Had a Bloomberg term routed into personal residence.. Brokers everywhere used to follow his calls like lemmings. His fame was cornering and profiting millions in one day on Yahoo IPO. Nothing shady, then he slipped into anonymity. True professional, if you asked him what looked good, he's tell you to eff off, never gave any secrets, even to family.

Topic.Title: Cramer Lovers

Message.Msg: I wired his Bloomberg term, the guy looked like an old hippie, tye-dye shirt, Birkenstocks, Grateful Dead playing on the stereo, smelled like he never took a shower but amassed millions. I think he passed away but then again my buddy Steve OD'ed on H back in 1998 after crashing his Dodge Viper into a wall. The perils that come with fast money....

Topic.Title: FYI

Message.Msg: Well, it's only logical. Most of us take it as a learning process. Minimize potential problems before they happen. not saying, even with your best effort, you won't get a #$%$ occasionally. Best thing there is refund, add to BBL eat the loss and have minimal contact, nothing personal ever. If a seller makes it personal, you're opening a can of worms.

Topic.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive

Message.Msg: Ebay's challenges today are now compounded by the disappointing results this afternoon from technology stalwarts GOOG and MSFT. This is in addition to the miss @ AXP, portending future weakness at PayPal. After hours, EBAY shares are continuing to decline. The EBAY correction has not yet established a sustainable support level.

Topic.Title: only a few dollar in commission

Message.Msg: Somehow, I get the feeling, you'll always be a bagholder. You're completely forgetting capital gains tax. Wait until you get your first IRS statement. Better get ready. Daytrading is not all it's cracked up to be and NOBODY will tell you what's in store for you.

Topic.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive

Message.Msg: eBay clearly stated financial guidance for the next year may be off. What do you need to see to know this is a company in trouble? All the trouble is compounded by the current CEO John Donahoe and his executive team. eBay will probably survive but they need to oust the CEO asap to get back on track.

Topic.Title: EBAY: Near Term Correction, Mid to Long Term Positive

Message.Msg: eBay is an extremely viable business. They started in P2P sales, and they need to head back that way. CEO John Donahoe has led the barrage against eBay being a "garage sale" venue but he betrayed the cash cow that made eBay. Let's be honest, NOBODY goes on eBay to look for designer clothing, etc... People go on eBay to look for collectibles, oddities, used items and deals. eBay is not Amazon, Amazon is not eBay. Each one fufills distinct consumer markets. John Donahoe thinks eBay buyers are looking for new, discount items when they're not. They can go to Amazon for that. eBay's originality lies in small P2P transactions.
